issues: Patient MAP is 59 mmHg, below the recommended >65 mmHg for safe contrast administration; the current protocol does not require hemodynamic stabilization before CTA.
Renal tool flagged creatinine as a critical fail and noted missing BMI, which is needed to calculate an appropriate weight‑based contrast dose.
Suggested contrast volume (100–150 mL) may be excessive for a patient with eGFR 59 mL/min/1.73 m² and hypotension; a reduced dose or low‑osmolar/iso‑osmolar agent is not mentioned.
Renal safety note uses an atypical metric (contrast‑to‑eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min)), which is not standard; the usual safety threshold is contrast volume/eGFR <3.7–4.0.
No explicit plan for immediate pre‑procedure renal labs (baseline creatinine) or post‑procedure monitoring beyond a generic statement.
Alternative imaging options (e.g., V/Q scan) are only suggested abstractly; no decision framework based on pre‑test probability (Wells score) is provided.
recommendations: Stabilize MAP to ≥65 mmHg with cautious fluid resuscitation or vasopressors before any contrast‑enhanced study; defer CTA until hemodynamics are acceptable.
Obtain current weight and calculate BMI; use this to determine a reduced, weight‑based contrast volume (e.g., 50–70 mL of low‑ or iso‑osmolar iodinated contrast) if CTA is still required.

Implement a standardized hydration protocol: 1 mL/kg/h isotonic saline for 12 hours pre‑ and post‑contrast (adjust for heart failure), or at minimum 0.5 mL/kg/h for 1–2 hours before and after if time‑critical.
Consider a split‑dose or low‑rate injection (e.g., 3–4 mL/s) to further reduce nephrotoxic risk.
If the clinical pre‑test probability for PE is low to intermediate, prefer a ventilation‑perfusion scan or bedside transthoracic echocardiography instead of CTA.
Document baseline creatinine and eGFR immediately before contrast; repeat serum creatinine at 24 h and 48 h post‑procedure to detect CIN.
Replace the erroneous contrast‑to‑eGFR safety metric with the widely accepted volume/eGFR ratio (<3.7 mL·min/1.73 m²) for decision‑making.
Include a clear statement that carotid CTA is not indicated for this presentation, and remove it from the protocol selection list.

statement_assessments.text: Patient MAP is 59 mmHg, below the recommended >65 mmHg for safe contrast administration; the current protocol does not require hemodynamic stabilization before CTA.
Renal tool flagged creatinine as a critical fail and noted missing BMI, which is needed to calculate an appropriate weight‑based contrast dose.
Suggested contrast volume (100–150 mL) may be excessive for a patient with eGFR 59 mL/min/1.73 m² and hypotension; a reduced dose or low‑osmolar/iso‑osmolar agent is not mentioned.
Renal safety note uses an atypical metric (contrast‑to‑eGFR ratio <1.1 g/(mL/min)), which is not standard; the usual safety threshold is contrast volume/eGFR <3.7–4.0.
No explicit plan for immediate pre‑procedure renal labs (baseline creatinine) or post‑procedure monitoring beyond a generic statement.
Alternative imaging options (e.g., V/Q scan) are only suggested abstractly; no decision framework based on pre‑test probability (Wells score) is provided.
Stabilize MAP to ≥65 mmHg with cautious fluid resuscitation or vasopressors before any contrast‑enhanced study; defer CTA until hemodynamics are acceptable.
Obtain current weight and calculate BMI; use this to determine a reduced, weight‑based contrast volume (e.g., 50–70 mL of low‑ or iso‑osmolar iodinated contrast) if CTA is still required.

Implement a standardized hydration protocol: 1 mL/kg/h isotonic saline for 12 hours pre‑ and post‑contrast (adjust for heart failure), or at minimum 0.5 mL/kg/h for 1–2 hours before and after if time‑critical.
Consider a split‑dose or low‑rate injection (e.g., 3–4 mL/s) to further reduce nephrotoxic risk.
If the clinical pre‑test probability for PE is low to intermediate, prefer a ventilation‑perfusion scan or bedside transthoracic echocardiography instead of CTA.
Document baseline creatinine and eGFR immediately before contrast; repeat serum creatinine at 24 h and 48 h post‑procedure to detect CIN.
Replace the erroneous contrast‑to‑eGFR safety metric with the widely accepted volume/eGFR ratio (<3.7 mL·min/1.73 m²) for decision‑making.
Include a clear statement that carotid CTA is not indicated for this presentation, and remove it from the protocol selection list.
